title: Constant mass in linear motion table

content.question: Time <math alttext="in seconds " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>s</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> Magnitude of the Applied Force <math alttext="in Newtons " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>N</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> A <math alttext="2 kilogram " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> object travels in the positive direction across a horizontal surface with a constant speed of <math alttext="10 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> . A force is exerted on the object for <math alttext="4 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the force increases linearly with respect to time. The table shows data about the magnitude of the applied force exerted on the object at different times. The force is exerted on the object in the opposite direction of the object’s displacement. What is the change in momentum of the object?

choices.label: <math alttext="8 newton seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the positive direction

<math alttext="8 newton seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the negative direction

<math alttext="16 newton seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>16</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the positive direction

<math alttext="16 newton seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>16</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the negative direction

content.answer: <math alttext="8 newton seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the negative direction

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
